string.name: plank_instructions

p.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 1.2rem 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px rgb(255, 255, 255); font-family: Merriweather, Verdana, Arial, serif; counter-reset: section 0; text-align: left; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-thickness: initial; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;

string.p: Select a position where you can extend your whole body length. Using an exercise mat will give you enough padding to be comfortable on all fours. You can choose whether to perform plank on your palms or your forearms, as shown in the video above.

div.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px rgb(255, 255, 255); text-align: left; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); font-family: Merriweather, Verdana, Arial, serif; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-thickness: initial; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;
box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px;

iframe.title: 3rd party ad content

ol.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0.625rem 0px 1.25rem 0.95rem; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px rgb(255, 255, 255); counter-reset: section 0; text-align: left; color: rgb(33, 33, 33); font-family: Merriweather, Verdana, Arial, serif; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-thickness: initial; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;

li.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px 0px 0.625rem 2.2em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px; list-style: none; position: relative;

ol.li: 1. Begin in the plank position, face down with your forearms and toes on the floor. Your elbows are directly under your shoulders and your forearms are facing forward. Your head is relaxed and you should be looking at the floor.

li.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px 0px 0.625rem 2.2em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px; list-style: none; position: relative;

ol.li: 2. Engage your abdominal muscles, drawing your navel toward your spine. Keep your torso straight and rigid and your body in a straight line from your ears to your toes with no sagging or bending. This is the neutral spine position. Ensure your shoulders are down, not creeping up toward your ears. Your heels should be over the balls of your feet.

li.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px 0px 0.625rem 2.2em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px; list-style: none; position: relative;

ol.li: 3. Hold this position for 10 seconds. Release to floor.

li.style: box-sizing: inherit; margin: 0px 0px 0.625rem 2.2em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: 400; vertical-align: baseline; background: 0px 0px; list-style: none; position: relative;

ol.li: 4. Over time work up to 30, 45, or 60 seconds.
